turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: It was illegal, what he did.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: You know, this kinda thing, you gotta be brutal.  A leak happens, the whole damn place should be fired.  Really. You do it like the Germans in World War II.  If they went through these towns and a sniper hit one of them, they'd line the whole goddamned town up and say: "Until you talk you're all getting shot."  I really think that's what has to be done.  I don't think you can be Mr. Nice-guy anymore ...

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: The lie?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: You remember, John, in '48 -- no one believed Alger Hiss was a communist. Except me.  They loved Hiss just like they loved this Ellsberg character. East Coast, Ivy League.  He was their kind.  I was dirt to them.  Nothing.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: And Dick beat the shit out of them.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: But I wouldn't have if Hiss hadn't lied about knowing Chambers.  The documents were old and out of date, like these Pentagon Papers.  The key thing we proved was that Hiss was a liar.  Then people bought it that he was a spy.  It's the lie that gets you.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Hiss was protecting his wife.  I've always believed that.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: When they know you've got something to protect, that's when they fuck you!

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Sorry, Dick.  She's a little tipsy.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: You mean smashed!  She called up at midnight last week.  Talking a bunch of crap.  Pat can't stand her.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: It's a thing she does.  She talks at night.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Talks all day, too!  How the hell can you put up with her, John?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: What the hell -- I love her.  And she's great in bed.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Rocky's full of shit!  No way he's going to get nominated west of the Hudson with a new wife.  He's gonna be drinking Scotches in retirement at some goddamn country club with the rest of the Republicans.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Goes to show you all the moolah in the world can't buy you a brain.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Well, he seems to have bought Kissinger.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: The Jewboy's a Harvard whore with the morals of an eel -- sells himself to the highest bidder.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: You're the one who should be in politics, John.  You're tougher than I am.  You never crack.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: That'll be the day.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Let's get out of here; it's too painful.  I hate it.  We went bowling last weekend.  Next weekend we're going to the zoo. Whoever said there was life after politics was full of shit.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Make some money, Dick, prove yourself to the Wall Street crowd and let Goldwater and Rockefeller take the fall against Kennedy.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Uh, wait ...

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: You need her, Dick -- in '60 she was worth five, six million votes.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Don't worry -- I'll use the old Nixon charm on her.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: How many?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Four.  Two boys.  Two girls.  And eight wounded.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Jesus Christ!

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: One of the fathers was on the TV saying, "My child was not a bum."  And it's playing like gangbusters.  Hell, Hoover told me one of the girls was a nymph.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Shit, the press doesn't care about the facts.  Cronkite's sticking it to me. It's their first big hit on Richard Nixon.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: This isn't '48, Dick.  They'll never buy it.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: How do you know that, John?  Did we try?  Are we just giving up like the rest of 'em?  What's Hoover found, for God's sake?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: You all right?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: My brother Harold was about the same age as those kids, John.  Tuberculosis got him.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: It wasn't your fault.  The soldiers were just kids, too.  They panicked.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: They were throwing rocks, John, just rocks.  They don't think I feel ... but I feel too much sometimes.  I just can't let a whole policy get dominated by our sentimentality.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: You're doing the right thing, Dick ... don't let 'em shake you.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: It broke my heart when Harold died.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: That was a long time ago.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Get off that.  That leads nowhere. You should offer condolences to the families of those kids.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Sure, I'd like to offer condolences.

turns.speaker: TOLSON
turns.text: ... give me a break, Mary.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: You all know me.  I'm one of you, I grew up a stone's throw from here on a little lemon ranch in Yorba Linda ...

turns.speaker: TOLSON
turns.text: But it was all we had.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: ... but it was all we had.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Edgar, wonderful to see you.  Clyde ... hi.

turns.speaker: TOLSON
turns.text: Mr. Nixon.

turns.speaker: TOLSON
turns.text: ... Somebody should shoot the little bastard.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: I wanna fight just as dirty as he does.

turns.speaker: TOLSON
turns.text: ... Use his women.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: ... Any information you have, Edgar. The sonofabitch is not gonna steal from me again!  Can you back me up on this?  Can I count on your support?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Hi, I'm Dick Nixon.

turns.speaker: STUDENT 2
turns.text: You're shittin' me.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Where you from?

turns.speaker: STUDENT 2
turns.text: Syracuse.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: The Orangemen!  Now there's a football program.  Jim Brown.  And that other tailback ... The one with the blood disease ...

turns.speaker: STUDENT 2
turns.text: Ernie Davis.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Right, right.  I used to play a little ball myself at Whittier.  Of course, they used me as a tackling dummy.

turns.speaker: STUDENT 2
turns.text: What you have to understand, Mr. Nixon, is that we are willing to die for what we believe in.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: That man up there lived in similar times.  He had chaos and civil war and hatred between the races ... Sometimes I go to the Lincoln Room at the White House and just pray.  You know, the liberals act like idealism belongs to them, but it's not true.  My family went Republican because Lincoln freed the slaves.  My grandmother was an abolitionist.  It was Quakers who founded Whittier, my hometown, to abolish slavery.  They were conservative Bible folk, but they had a powerful sense of right and wrong ... Forty years ago I was looking, as you are now, for answers.  But you know, ending the war and cleaning up the air and the cities, feeding the poor -- my mother used to feed hobos stopping over at our house - none of it is going to satisfy the spiritual hunger we all have, finding a meaning to this life ...

turns.speaker: STUDENT 2
turns.text: Come on, man -- Vietnam ain't Germany. It doesn't threaten us.  It's a civil war between the Vietnamese.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: But change always comes slowly.  I've withdrawn more than half the troops. I'm trying to cut the military budget for the first time in thirty years.  I want an all-volunteer army.  But it's also a question of American credibility, our position in the world ...

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Hello ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: That's Julie ... and that's Tricia. She, uh, reminds me a little bit of you ...

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Oh yeah ... she really is ... wholesome.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: ... I don't really know you yet, Sandy ... What do you like?  I mean, what kind of clothes do you like?  Do you like blue ... red?

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Oh, I like satin, I like pink ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: What kind of, uh ... music do you like?

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: I like jazz ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Yeah ... Guy Lombardo ...

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Elvis I like, too.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Oh yeah, he's good.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: ... but it depends on what I'm doing to the music, Dick ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Uh, is your mother ... still alive?

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Yeah, she lives in Dallas ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: She must be very attractive.  Would she like an autograph?  She might remember me ... Where's Trini?

turns.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
turns.text: We didn't come here to talk about football.  We came here to end the war.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Yes, I understand that.

turns.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
turns.text: No, we don't!  You're full of shit! You say you want to end the war, so why don't you?  My brother died over there last November.  Why?  What good was his death?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: I know.  I know.  I've seen a lot of kids die, too, in World War II.

turns.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
turns.text: Someone wants it ...  You can't stop it, can you?  Even if you wanted to.  Because it's not you. It's the system.  And the system won't let you stop it ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: There's a lot more at stake here than what you want.  Or even what I want ...

turns.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
turns.text: Then what's the point?  What's the point of being president?  You're powerless.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: No, no.  I'm not powerless.  Because ... because I understand the system. I believe I can control it.  Maybe not control it totally.  But ... tame it enough to make it do some good.

turns.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
turns.text: It sounds like you're talking about a wild animal.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Maybe I am.

turns.speaker: ZIEGLER
turns.text: We got the press this time!

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: And we got the "big mo"!  We're back!

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: We gotta make 'em think we're just as tough as they are -- that Nixon's a mad bomber, he might do anything!  I played a lot of poker in World War II , and I won big, and let me tell you this -- unpredictability is our best asset.  That redneck Johnson left me with a shitty hand and I'm bluffing.  I've got to play the hawk in Vietnam and the dove in China. And if we keep our heads, we can win this thing.

turns.speaker: ZIEGLER
turns.text: What?  Win Vietnam, sir?

turns.speaker: ZIEGLER
turns.text: But what am I telling the press about Kent State?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Tell 'em what you like; they'll never understand it anyway.

turns.speaker: ZIEGLER
turns.text: Mr. President, the press guys asked if you could come back for a minute.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: The hell with 'em.

turns.speaker: ZIEGLER
turns.text: No, they want you, Mr. President.  I really think it would be a good move.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Gentlemen, I go now to discover the exact length, width and depth of the shaft.

turns.speaker: ZIEGLER
turns.text: Bernstein.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Who the fuck are they?  Bob, are you working on revoking the Posts's television license?  Good.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: You know, Fred, they sell tickets.

turns.speaker: ZIEGLER
turns.text: Sir?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: They sell tickets to an impeachment. Like a fucking circus ... Okay, so they impeach me.  Then it's a question of mathematics.  How many votes do we have in the Senate?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Shit, plenty of people did their best writing in prison.  Gandhi, Lenin ...

turns.speaker: ZIEGLER
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: What I know about this country, I ... I could rip it apart.  If they want a public humiliation, that's what they'll get.  But I will never resign this office.  Where the fuck am I?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: What's in there?

turns.speaker: ZIEGLER
turns.text: POWs.  And their families.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: So I'm supposed to be ...

turns.speaker: ZIEGLER
turns.text: Compassionate.  Grateful.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Proud?

turns.speaker: ZIEGLER
turns.text: Sir?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Of them.

turns.speaker: ZIEGLER
turns.text: Yes, yes.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Fire him.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: There's more ... there's more than just me.  You can't break, my boy, even when there's nothing left.  You can't admit, even to yourself, that it's gone, Al.  Do you think those POWs in there did?

turns.speaker: ZIEGLER
turns.text: No, sir ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Now some people, we both know them, Al, think you can go stand in the middle of the bullring and cry, "Mea culpa, mea culpa," while the crowd is hissing and booing and spitting on you.  But a man doesn't cry.  I don't cry.  You don't cry ... You fight!

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: And this?!  Good Lord, have you lost your mind?  Nixon can't say this. "Niggers"!

turns.speaker: ZIEGLER
turns.text: Well, we could delete it.

turns.speaker: ZIEGLER
turns.text: Or we could write "expletive deleted."

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: ... and get rid of all these "goddamns" and "Jesus Christs"!

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: We lost ...

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: I know ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: It's hard to lose ...

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: It makes us human ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: It's not fair, Buddy.  I can take the insults; I can take the name-calling. But I can't take the losing.  I hate it.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: We don't have to put ourselves through this again, Dick.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: What do you mean?  We worked for it. We earned it.  It's ours.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: It is.  We know that.  And it's enough that we know.  Just think of the girls.  They're still young.  We never see them.  I lost my parents.  I don't want them to lose theirs; I don't want them to grow up without a mother and father ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Maybe I should get out of the game. What do you think, Buddy?  Go back to being a lawyer and end up with something solid, some money at the end of the line ... You know, I keep thinking of my old man tonight.  He was a failure, too.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: You're not a failure, Dick.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: You know how much money he had in the bank when he died?  Nothing.  He was so damned honest ...  But I miss him.  I miss him a hell of a lot.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Thank you, Fidel Castro.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: You're not going to blame this on Castro, are you?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: I sure am.  The goddamned missile crisis united the whole country behind Kennedy.  And he was supporting Brown. People were scared, that's why.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: I suppose Castro staged the whole thing just to beat you.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Buddy, before you join the jubilation at my being beaten again, you should remember: People vote not out of love, but fear.  They don't teach that at Sunday School or at the Whittier Community Playhouse!

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Don't you want to listen to Brown's victory speech?

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: No.  I'm not going to listen to any more speeches ever again.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Amen to that.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: It's over, Dick.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: I'll concede in the morning.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: Not that.  Us.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: What are you saying?  What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: I want a divorce.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: My God -- divorce?  What about the girls?

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: The girls will grow up.  They only know you from television anyway.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: It would ruin us, Buddy, our family.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: You're ruining us.  If we stay with you, you'll take us down with you.  This isn't political, Dick.  This is our life.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Everything's political, for Christ's sake!  I'm political.  And you're political, too!

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: No, I'm not!  I'm finished.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: This is just what they want, Buddy. Don't you see it?  They want to drive us apart.  To beat us.  We can't let them do it.  We've been through too much together, Buddy ... We belong together.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: That's what you said the first time we met.  You didn't even know me.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: Dick, don't...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Buddy, look at me ... just look at me. Do you really want me to quit?

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: We can be happy.  We really can.  We love you, Dick.  The girls and I...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: If I stop ... there'll be no more talk of divorce?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: I'll do it.  No more.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: Are you serious?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Yeah ... I'm out.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: Is that the truth?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: I'll never run again.  I promise.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: Dick, you should call Bobby.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: He doesn't want me at the funeral.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: You don't have to go.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: De Gaulle's gonna be there.  And Macmillan.  And Adenauer. Nixon can't not be there.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: Then call him.  I'm sure it was an oversight.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: No.  It's his way.  He hates me.  Him and Teddy.  They always hated me.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: They've lost a brother.  You know what that means, Dick.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: Were you planning to tell me?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: We ... haven't announced anything ... uh ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Buddy? ...

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: You should be going ... the primaries are soon, aren't they?  New Hampshire ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: They love you, Buddy.  They need you, too.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: I don't want them to love me.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: I need you out there.  It won't be like last time.  The war's crippled the Democrats.  I can win ... We deserve it.  Yeah, it's ours, Buddy -- at last.  Nobody knows better than you.  Frank Nixon's boy.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: It was our dream, too, Buddy, together ... always.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: Do you really want this, Dick?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: This.  Above all.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: And then you'll be happy?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Yes ... you know it!  Yes ... I will. Yeah!

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: Then I'll be there for you.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: You're the strongest woman I ever met. I love you, Buddy.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: Can I just ask for one thing?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Anything.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: Will you ... would you kiss me?

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: He looked old, didn't he?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: I asked him, "Lyndon, what would you do, on a scale of one to ten?"  And he said, "Bomb the shit out of Hanoi, boy!  Bomb them where they live." ... John, do you think I was too soft on TV?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Hi, Buddy.  What are you doing in here?

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: I've missed you.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Are you okay?

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: Why don't we go down to Key Biscayne together?  Just the two of us.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Because ... I have to relax.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: I was thinking tonight -- do you remember, Dick?  Do you remember when you used to drive me on dates with the other boys?  You didn't want to let me out of your sight.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Yeah, sure, a long time ago.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: Yes, it's been a long time ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: I don't need that, Buddy.  I'm not Jack Kennedy.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: No, you're not.  So stop comparing yourself to him.  You have no reason to ... You have everything you ever wanted. You've earned it.  Why can't you just enjoy it?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: I do.  I do.  In my own way.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: Then what are you scared of, honey?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: I'm not scared, Buddy.  You don't understand.  They're playing for keeps, Buddy.  The press, the kids, the liberals -- they're out there, trying to figure out how to tear me down.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: They're all your enemies?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Yes!

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: You personally?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Yes!  This is about me.  Why can't you understand that, you of all people? It's not the war -- it's Nixon!  They want to destroy Nixon!  And if I expose myself even the slightest bit they'll tear my insides out.  Do you want that?  Do you want to see that, Buddy?  It's not pretty.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: Sometimes I think that's what you want.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: You've been drinking.  What the hell are you saying?  Jesus, you sound like them now! ...  I've gotta keep fighting, Buddy, for the country.  These people running things, the elite ... they're soft, chickenshit faggots!  They don't have the long-term vision anymore.  They just want to cover their asses or meet girls or tear each other down.  Oh, God, this country's in deep trouble, Buddy ... and I have to see this through.  Mother would've wanted no less of me ... I'm sorry, Buddy.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: No, I don't.  I'm not Jack ...

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: But they never will, Dick.  No matter how many elections you win, they never will.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: Penny for your thoughts.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Is that adjusted for inflation?  Think of the life Mao's led.  In '52 I called him a monster.  Now he could be our most important ally.  Only Nixon could've done that.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: You're a long way from Whittier.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: Congratulations, Dick.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: How am I going to break this to Bob Hope?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Not for the Pentagon it isn't.  I'm kissing Mao's ass.  And the press is gonna find some way to shaft Nixon on this one.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: It's not the press that matters. Nixon's wife is proud of him.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: When?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Tomorrow.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: Ron told me that Bob Haldeman's been calling.  But you won't talk to him ... if he's convicted, will you pardon him?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: What exactly did you want to discuss, Pat?

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: You.  What' you're doing --

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: And what am I doing?

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: I wish I knew.  You're hiding.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Hiding what?

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: Whatever it is you've always been hiding.  You're letting it destroy you, Dick.  You won't even ask for help.  You're destroying yourself, Dick.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: I'm the only left, Dick.  If you don't talk to me, you ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Brezhnev's coming in three days.  I don't want to deal with them.  And him.  And you.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: No, it isn't.  I won't interfere with you anymore.  I'm finished trying.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: Thank you?  Dick, sometimes I understand why they hate you.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: Why didn't you?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: You can't expect me to explain that to you.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: What matters to me is whether you understand it.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: You don't expect me to believe that for one minute, do you?  Does it matter what's on them? Really? ... Murder, Dick?  Sex?  Your secrets, your fantasies?  Or just me and you and ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Don't be ridiculous!

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: I remember Alger Hiss.  I know how ugly you can be -- you're capable of anything.  But you see, it doesn't really matter, at the end of the day, what's on them.  Because you have absolutely no remorse.  No concept of remorse.  You want the tapes to get out, you want them to see you at your worst ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: You're drunk!

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: And what would I find out that I haven't known for years.  What makes it so damn sad is that you couldn't confide in any of us. You had to make a record ... for the whole world.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: They were for me.  They're mine.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: No.  They're not yours.  They are you. You should burn them.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: It'll be over soon.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: No ... it's just going to start now ...  If I could just ... If I could just ... sleep.

turns.speaker: PAT
turns.text: There'll be time for that.

turns.speaker: ROCKEFELLER
turns.text: Howya doin'!  New York treating you okay?  I'm sorry I haven't been able to see you at all--

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Well enough.  You're looking "happy," Nelson.

turns.speaker: ROCKEFELLER
turns.text: Oh, Happy!  Dick Nixon ... You remember him.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Hi, Happy.  Well, you're obviously making him happy.

turns.speaker: ROCKEFELLER
turns.text: Repartee, Dick -- very good.  Hey, I feel ten years younger!  It makes a helluva difference, let me tell ya! How's the lawyer life?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Never made so much money in my life. But my upbringing doesn't allow me to enjoy it.  I did get to argue a case before the Supreme Court.

turns.speaker: ROCKEFELLER
turns.text: Won or lost?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Lost.

turns.speaker: ROCKEFELLER
turns.text: Someday, Dick.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: But being out of the game gives me time to write.

turns.speaker: ROCKEFELLER
turns.text: To what?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Write.  You know, a book.  I'm calling it "Six Crises."  It's a good thing, Rocky -- take some time off to write.

turns.speaker: ROCKEFELLER
turns.text: Hiya, fellow ... What were they?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ROCKEFELLER
turns.text: The "crises"?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: "Checkers" of course, Hiss, Ike's heart attack, Venezuela, the Kitchen Debate, and Kennedy.

turns.speaker: ROCKEFELLER
turns.text: Sounds like you got a crisis syndrome. Aren't you exaggerating a bit, Dick? Call it three-and-a-half, maybe four ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Let's wait and see how you survive your first crisis, Rocky ...

turns.speaker: ROCKEFELLER
turns.text: Whatcha mean by that?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: You know: how the voters are gonna play your divorce.

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Well, in any case, Rocky, I'll send you my book.  "Six Crises."

turns.speaker: ROCKEFELLER
turns.text: Whatcha predicting -- your boy Goldwater going to split the party?

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: Some say you are, Rocky.

turns.speaker: ROCKEFELLER
turns.text: The Republican Party was never home to extremists.  You should know better. This guy's as stupid as McCarthy, and McCarthy never did you any good in the long run, now did he?

turns.speaker: ROCKEFELLER
turns.text: Hey, you know Henry Kissinger -- he's down from Harvard.  On my staff, foreign policy whiz ...

turns.speaker: NIXON
turns.text: No, but I liked your book on nuclear weapons.  We have similar views on the balance of power ...

turns.speaker: ROCKEFELLER
turns.text: Well, that's wonderful.  So get me this "crisis" thing, Dick; I'll be glad to take a look at it.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: How'd you know I was here.

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: Who else'd be in your truck.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: You heard it?

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: How's that?

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: You heard my -- you havin' fun with me?

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: What give you that idea. I seen one of the cats heard it.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: But -- how'd you know it was mine?

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: I deduced it. Once you walked in.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: How many a those things you got now?

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: Cats? Several. Wal. Depends what you mean by got. Some are half-wild, and some are just outlaws.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: How you been, Ellis?

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: You lookin' at it. I got to say you look older.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: I am older.

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: Got a letter from your wife. She writes pretty regular, tells me the family news.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: Didn't know there was any.

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: She just told me you was quittin'. Sit down.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: Want a cup?

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: 'Predate it.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: How fresh is this coffee?

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: I generally make a fresh pot ever week even if there's some left over.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: That man that shot you died in prison.

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: In Angola. Yeah.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: What would you a done if he'd been released?

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: I don't know. Nothin'. Wouldn't be no point to it.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: I'm kindly surprised to hear you say that.

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: All the time you spend tryin' to get back what's been took from you there's more goin' out the door. After a while you just try and get a tourniquet on it.

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: ...Your granddad never asked me to sign on as deputy. I done that my own self. Loretta says you're quittin'.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: Yes, you've circled round.

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: How come're you doin that?

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: I don't know. I feel overmatched.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: ...I always thought when I got older God would sort of come into my life in some way. He didn't. I don't blame him. If I was him I'd have the same opinion about me that he does.

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: You don't know what he thinks.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: Yes I do.

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: ...Shot down on his own porch there in Hudspeth County. There was seven or eight of 'em come to the house. Wantin' this and wantin' that. Mac went back in and got his shotgun but they was way ahead of him. Shot him down in his own doorway.  Aunt Ella run out and tried to stop the bleedin'. Him tryin to get hold of the shotgun again. They just set there on their horses watchin' him die. Finally one of 'em says somethin' in Injun and they all turned and left out. Well Mac knew the score even if Aunt Ella didn't. Shot through the left lung and that was that. As they say.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: When did he die?

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: Nineteen zero and nine.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: No, I mean was it right away or in the night or when was it.

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: Believe it was that night. She buried him the next mornin'.  Diggin' in that hard caliche.

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: ...What you got ain't nothin' new. This country is hard on people. Hard and crazy. Got the devil in it yet folks never seem to hold it to account.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: Most don't.

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: You're discouraged.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: I'm... discouraged.

turns.speaker: ELLIS
turns.text: You can't stop what's comin. Ain't all waitin' on you.

turns.speaker: ROSCOE
turns.text: I thought maybe she was with your boy there.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: No ID in her room?

turns.speaker: ROSCOE
turns.text: Not hardly nothin' in her room. And that establishment was no stickler on registration. Well...

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: No money in his room there?

turns.speaker: ROSCOE
turns.text: Couple hundred on his person. Those hombres would've taken the stash.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: I suppose. Though they was leavin' in a hurry.

turns.speaker: ROSCOE
turns.text: It's all the goddamned money, Ed Tom. The money and the drugs.  It's just goddamned beyond everything. What is it mean? What is it leading to?

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ROSCOE
turns.text: If you'd a told me twenty years ago I'd see children walkin' the streets of our Texas towns with green hair and bones in their noses I just flat out wouldn't of believed you.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: Signs and wonders. But I think once you stop hearin' sir and madam the rest is soon to follow.

turns.speaker: ROSCOE
turns.text: It's the tide. It's the dismal tide. It is not the one thing.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: Not the one thing. I used to think I could at least some way put things right. I don't feel that way no more.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: ...I don't know what I do feel like.

turns.speaker: ROSCOE
turns.text: Try "old" on for size.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: Yessir. It may be that. In a nutshell.

turns.speaker: ROSCOE
turns.text: None of that explains your man though.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: ROSCOE
turns.text: He is just a goddamn homicidal lunatic, Ed Tom.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: I'm not sure he's a lunatic.

turns.speaker: ROSCOE
turns.text: Well what would you call him.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: I don't know. Sometimes I think he's pretty much a ghost.

turns.speaker: ROSCOE
turns.text: He's real all right.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: Oh yes.

turns.speaker: ROSCOE
turns.text: All that at the Eagle Hotel. It's beyond everything.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: Yes, he has some hard bark on him.

turns.speaker: ROSCOE
turns.text: That don't hardly say it. He shoots the desk clerk one day, and walks right back in the next and shoots a retired army colonel.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: Hard to believe.

turns.speaker: ROSCOE
turns.text: Strolls right back into a crime scene. Who would do such a thing? How do you defend against it?

turns.speaker: CARLA JEAN
turns.text: Don't know why I did. I told you, I don't know where he is.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: You ain't heard from him?

turns.speaker: CARLA JEAN
turns.text: No I ain't.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: Nothin'?

turns.speaker: CARLA JEAN
turns.text: Not word one.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: Would you tell me if you had?

turns.speaker: CARLA JEAN
turns.text: Well, I don't know. He don't need any trouble from you.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: It's not me he's in trouble with.

turns.speaker: CARLA JEAN
turns.text: Who's he in trouble with then?

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: Some pretty bad people.

turns.speaker: CARLA JEAN
turns.text: Llewelyn can take care of hisself.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: These people will kill him, Carla Jean. They won't quit.

turns.speaker: CARLA JEAN
turns.text: He won't neither. He never has.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: I wish I could say that was in his favor. But I have to say I don't think it is.

turns.speaker: CARLA JEAN
turns.text: He can take all comers.

turns.speaker: CARLA JEAN
turns.text: Why you tellin' me that, Sheriff?

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: I don't know. My mind wanders.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: Who's Charlie Walser. Oh! Well, I, uh... True story? I couldn't swear to ever detail but... it's certainly true that it is a story.

turns.speaker: CARLA JEAN
turns.text: Yeah, right. Sheriff, can you give me your word on somethin'?

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: Yes ma'am?

turns.speaker: CARLA JEAN
turns.text: If I tell you where Llewelyn's headed, you promise it'll be just you goes and talks with him -- you and nobody else?

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: Yes ma'am, I do.

turns.speaker: CARLA JEAN
turns.text: Llewelyn would never ask for help. He never thinks he needs any.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: Carla Jean, I will not harm your man. And he needs help, whether he knows it or not.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: Carla Jean...

turns.speaker: CARLA JEAN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: You wouldn't think a car would burn like that.

turns.speaker: WENDELL
turns.text: Yessir. We should a brought wieners.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: Does that look to you like about a '77 Ford, Wendell?

turns.speaker: WENDELL
turns.text: It could be.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: I'd say it is. Not a doubt in my mind.

turns.speaker: WENDELL
turns.text: The old boy shot by the highway?

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: Yessir, his vehicle. Man killed Lamar's deputy, took his car, killed someone on the highway, swapped for his car, and now here it is and he's swapped again for god knows what.

turns.speaker: WENDELL
turns.text: That's very linear Sheriff.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: Well. Old age flattens a man.

turns.speaker: WENDELL
turns.text: Yessir. But then there's this other. He nods up the ridge away from the highway.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: ...You ride Winston.

turns.speaker: WENDELL
turns.text: You sure?

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: Oh, I'm more than sure. Anything happens to Loretta's horse I can tell you right now you don't wanna be the party that was aboard.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: I know this truck. Belongs to a feller named Moss.

turns.speaker: WENDELL
turns.text: Llewelyn Moss?

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: That's the boy.

turns.speaker: WENDELL
turns.text: You figure him for a dope runner?

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: Yes, appears to have been a glitch or two.

turns.speaker: WENDELL
turns.text: What calibers you got there, Sheriff?

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: Nine millimeter. Couple of .45 ACP's.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: ...Somebody unloaded on this thing with a shotgun.

turns.speaker: WENDELL
turns.text: Mm.

turns.speaker: WENDELL
turns.text: ...How come do you reckon the coyotes ain't been at 'em?

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: I don't know...

turns.speaker: WENDELL
turns.text: These boys is all swole up. So this was earlier: gettin set to trade. Then, whoa, differences... You know: might not of even been no money.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: That's possible.

turns.speaker: WENDELL
turns.text: But you don't believe it.

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: No. Probably I don't.

turns.speaker: WENDELL
turns.text: It's a mess, ain't it Sheriff?

turns.speaker: WENDELL
turns.text: We goin' in?

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: Gun out and up.

turns.speaker: WENDELL
turns.text: What about yours?

turns.speaker: BELL
turns.text: I'm hidin' behind you.
